myopenmath.statement:
In one version of Snell's Law contains the ratio \displaystyle{\frac{{{V}_{{1}}}}{{{V}_{{2}}}}} where the \displaystyle{V}_{{i}} are the speeds of sound in two materials (like brass and cast iron). The goal is to determine if the units for velocity make a difference.
Suppose \displaystyle{V}_{{1}}={4300} m/s and \displaystyle{V}_{{2}}={4600} m/s. Calculate \displaystyle\frac{{V}_{{1}}}{{V}_{{2}}}=
The resulting units (of the ratio) are
none
m
m2
s
s2
/
none
m
m2
s
s2
.
Convert the units to feet per second.
\displaystyle{V}_{{1}}= ft/s
\displaystyle{V}_{{2}}= ft/s
Using the new units calculate \displaystyle\frac{{V}_{{1}}}{{V}_{{2}}}=
Did changing the units change the result?
no
yes
Explain:
